com.nokia.nfc.nxp.simpletag
Interface SimpleTagConnection

All Superinterfaces:
javax.microedition.contactless.TagConnection
public interface SimpleTagConnection
extends javax.microedition.contactless.TagConnection

SimpleTagConnection interface defines the necessary methods for reading and writing data and for other basic operations of the Simple Tag RFID ICs.

The connection supports two kinds of addressing modes: physical and logical. When using physical addressing one can read and write from any part of the tag and the offset to the memory area is specified using a block number. First block number is 0 and the last is getBlockAmount() - 1. In logical addressing only the user data areas can be read and written, and one defines the memory offset using a byte number (0-n). Physical addressing is used by the methods read(int, int) and write(int, byte[]). Logical addressing is used by readLogical(int, int) and writeLogical(int, byte[]).

read

byte[] read(int startBlock,
            int length)
            throws java.io.IOException,
                   javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                   java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Reads the specified blocks from the tag.

Parameters:
startBlock - number of the first block to read.
length - number of blocks to read.
Returns:
the read blocks.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if reading fails due to some other than a connection error.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the parameters define an illegal range of blocks.

write

void write(int startBlock,
           byte[] data)
           throws java.io.IOException,
                  javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                  java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                  java.lang.NullPointerException
Writes the given data to the tag starting from the specified block. If the length of the data array isn't a multiple of the block size, then extra zeroes will be written to the end to fit the block size.

Parameters:
startBlock - number of the block from which to start writing from.
data - the data to write to the tag.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if writing fails because of write protection.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the startPage is out of range.
java.lang.NullPointerException - if the given data array is null.

writeOTP

void writeOTP(byte[] otp)
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                     java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                     java.lang.NullPointerException
Writes the one time programmable (OTP) value to a SimpleTag tag. An existing OTP value on a tag will be combined with the new value using an OR operator. otp[0] will be written to the first OTP byte on the tag.

Parameters:
otp - the OTP bytes.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if writing failed because the OTP area is locked.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the otp array length is not valid.
java.lang.NullPointerException - if the otp array is null.
See Also:
OTP_SIZE

lockBlock

void lockBlock(int blockNumber)
               throws java.io.IOException,
                      javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

Locks a single SimpleTag block so that the contents of the block cannot be changed anymore.

Locking will fail if locking of the specified block number is prevented. In this case an ContactlessException will be thrown.

If the tag is a Mifare Ultralight tag then block numbers 0, 1 and 2 can be used for disabling locking of particular blocks. The change is permanent. Using block number 0 will disable locking the OTP area, block number 1 will disable locking blocks 4-9 and block number 2 will disable locking blocks 10-15.

Parameters:
blockNumber - number of the block to lock.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if locking fails due to some other than a connection error.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the block number is invalid.

lockBlocks

void lockBlocks(int[] blockNumbers)
                throws java.io.IOException,
                       javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                       java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Locks multiple blocks on a SimpleTag. ALL_DATA_BLOCKS can be used as a block number value in order to lock all of the user data blocks.

Parameters:
blockNumbers - numbers of the blocks to lock.
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if locking fails due to some other than a connection error.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a block number is invalid.
See Also:
lockBlock(int)

             throws java.io.IOException,

java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.

isWritable

boolean isWritable(int blockNumber,
                   byte[] lockBytes)
                   throws java.io.IOException,
                          javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException,
                          java.lang.IllegalArgumentException

Checks whether a given block is writable. The byte array parameter enables checking writability of an block without communicating with the tag by using the lock bytes read earlier using the readLockBytes() method. If the array parameter is null then the lock bytes are first read from the tag.

If ALL_DATA_BLOCKS is used as block number then this method checks if the entire data area is writable.

Parameters:
blockNumber - block number.
lockBytes - lock bytes of an Simpletag. null if not available.
Returns:
true if the given block is writable. false if not.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the block number is invalid or lockBytes length is not supported.
java.io.IOException - if a connection error occurs.
javax.microedition.contactless.ContactlessException - if reading fails due to some other than a connection error.
